SHORT_DESCR.P: The programme More Income and Employment in Rural Areas of Malawi aims to link smallholder farmers, their organizations and MSME with formal or structured marketing channels which will enable them to add value, access higher-value markets and thus create an enabling environment in which rural income and employment can be increased. KULIMA MIERA’s objective is to promote inclusive business and new marketing models. It identifies entry points in line with private sector priorities and ultimately targets smallholder farmers, their organizations and MSME in rural areas of Malawi.

KULIMA MIERA, therefore, applies a market-led value chain approach, focusing on building the capacity and resilience of local systems, leveraging the incentives and resources of the private sector and ensuring the beneficial inclusion of the poor.

Through its approach described above, the programme has been supporting the development of the following value chains and sectors over the last 2 years: soya, groundnut, sunflower, cassava, tourism and environmentally-friendly construction materials.
Capitalizing on the recently approved co-financing from the European Union, the programme will pursue the following scaling up strategies along agricultural value chains:
1. Intensifying support through current entry points – more beneficiaries and interventions through existing partner landscape;
2. Undertaking new activities through new partnerships in soya, groundnuts, sunflower and cassava – additional partners and entry points in existing value chains;
3. Supporting two to three additional agricultural value chains.
The Firm of Consultants shall also be responsible for designing tailored strategies to improve the provision of services along the selected value chains.

Following the KULIMA MIERA programme approach, the Firm of Consultants is expected to plan, implement and monitor activities and interventions in the areas: D.1 Output A: Promoting inclusive business models and stakeholder dialogue to build stronger cooperation between the stakeholders in the value chains. Building on the products of the value chain analysis and selection process, the Firm of Consultants will be tasked to finalize the design and negotiation of specific inclusive business model projects with lead companies and overall value chain development plans. Further The activities of the Firm of Consultants under this intervention area shall include planning, design and delivery of training and coaching concepts appropriate for the value chains selected and consistent with the needs and approaches of key partners selected. The Firm of Consultants shall be required to collaborate closely with the KULIMA MIERA programme team to ensure harmony in the collaboration with key partners, farmers, farmer organizations and MSME; and consistency of approaches.
Further information can be downloaded from our internet page for procurement and bidding opportunities.

RENEWAL_DESCR.P: Extention and prolongation of the duration of the Firm of Consultant’s contract resulting of this tender and increase the budget accordingly if and when the extension of the BMZ commission is confirmed and funding (e.g. EU) is available for additional services: These are, but not limited to, the prolongation of long-term experts and possible extension of short-term-experts etc.

INFO_ADD.P: The MIERA program is co-financed by the EU.

ECONOMIC_FINANCIAL_MIN_LEVEL.P: Mandatory grounds for exclusion as per section 123 GWB and optional as per section 124 GWB; evidence of commercial registry; declaration by consortium; average annual turnover for last 3 financial years/1 500 000 EUR; number of employees at 31.12. of previous year: at least 20 persons.

TECHNICAL_PROFESSIONAL_MIN_LEVEL.P: Reference projects with a minimum commission value of 300 000 EUR.
At least 5 reference projects in the field value chain development/support; private sector development and 2 reference in the region east/southern Africa in the last 3 years.

INFO_ADD.P: According to Article 160, Section 3 of the German Act Against Restraint of Competition, application for re-examination is not permissible insofar as:

1. the applicant has identified the claimed infringement of the contract award regulations before submitting the application for re-examination and has not submitted a complaint to the commissioning party within a period of 10 calendar days; the expiry of the period pursuant to Article 134, Section 2 remains unaffected;

2. complaints of infringements of contract award regulations that are evident in the notice are not submitted to the commissioning party at the latest by the expiry of the deadline for the application specified in the notice or by the deadline for the submission of bids;

3. complaints of infringements 5/5 of contract award regulations that first become evident in the tender documents are not submitted to the commissioning party at the latest by the expiry of the deadline for application or for the submission of bids;

4. more than 15 calendar days have elapsed after receipt of the notification from the commissioning party that it is unwilling to redress the complaint. Sentence 1 does not apply in the case of an application to determine the invalidity of the contract in accordance with Article 135, Section 1 (2). Article 134, Section 1, Sentence 2 remains unaffected.
